VOL. XLIV No. 25

The campus will be ready for "No More Peace" the Barnstormer's war

audience will discover that the play is liberally endowed with light moments;

Singewald speaks on war minerals
at Tau Beta Pi semi-annual tap
Geologist says Germany
lacks mineral power
Speaking as the second lecturer in
a series of non-compulsory assemblies sponsored by the NEWS-LETTER
and the Assembly committee, Dr J
T Singewald discussed yesterday the
Importance of mineral resources in
the current war. As an illustration of
the great role these resources play in
determining the political structure
of a nation, Dr Singewald stated
that it was largely through their
absence that totalitarian governments
come into being.
"Countries are divided into the
have got and the haven't got", the
lecturer stated, "and on this crux
hangs their foreign policies." The
current alignment of nations seems
to bear out this fact, as Germany
may have to depend largely on the resources of Russia, while the British
empire is in position to supply the
Allies. However, these lines of supply
are in turn dependent on the control
of transportation and commerce, and
that control is easily variable.
Dr Singewald divided the pertinent
resources into three groups; the nonmetals, the metals, and fuel. Both
sides in the conflict are adequately
supplied with the non-metals, composed mainly of fertilizers; both also
have plenty of coal and either petroleum or a synthetic substitute. In regard to metals, however, a different
picture is presented. Germany has
neither gold nor silver, and must depend on exports for cerdit—and these
exports will be seriously diminished
by the war. Germany also is in a
critical situation in regard to many
metals of war, and is notably short
of mercury, the source of fulminate.
Dr Singewald stated that in respect
to this and antimony, the question
has been raised as to whether Germany has been able to stock up a
supply; she probably has not, due to
the stringent circumstances of the
last few years.
As an illustration of the importance of colonies, Dr Singewald showed the relatively poor status of England alone and the great resources
at her command with the addition
of her colonies. Now there are only
two metals at all strategic for the
Allies, and they may be had from
neutral nations. Germany, on the
other hand, has twelve critical necessities, all of which may be had except two, assuming the support of
Russia.
The next and last lecture in the
series on the international scene will
be presented January 11 by Dr Kent
Roberts Greenfield, who will discuss
the Mediterranean region and its
significance in the war.

Hullabaloo
The proofs of the pictures
taken for the Hullabaloo last
week are already distributed,
and 111116:: be returned next
Tuesday, December 19, in the
Hullabaloo office between 10
and 4 o'clock. The proofs
should be returned in person at
the office, and not given to any
member of the staff. If the
proofs are returned on time,
the pictures ordered will be
ready during the Christmas
vacation.

Council approves
Honor appointees
The six new appointees to the
Honor commission were unanimously
approved at a meeting of the Student council on Friday, December 8.
The Freshman representatives are
Bob Burr, Robert Cross, Peter Stern
and Morty Hack, John McGee and
Wray Hoffman are the two upper
classmen just elected to the commission.
The Louisiana State university has
recently written to the commission
about the honor system. Stating the
fact that L S U would like to institute a similar system, the letter
asked about the workings of the plan
here at the Hopkins and about the
rules governing its application.
Some members of the Commission
believe that the freshman class does
not understand the full import of
the honor system. If necessary, the
Honor commission plans a further
period of education similar to the
one the new students had at the beginning of the academic year.

Hague, Depkin, Gosnell,
Gray, Bauer boys tapped
Tau Beta Pi, honorary engineering
men at a

fraternity, inducted six

public tap preceding Dr Singewald'P
address at the assembly yesterday.
Four seniors—Charles Hague, Charles
Depkin, John Gray, and Don Bauer,
and two juniors—William Gosnell
and Jack Bauer, were admitted.
After a short explanation of the
requirements and purpose of the fraternity, Charles Rothauge, chapter
president, brought the six men up to
the stage and awarded each his bent.
Although the primary requisite for
membership is scholarship, most of
the entrants have engaged in extracurricular activities. Gosnell, a football player for the past two years, is
also president of his class. Hague and
Depkin are active in intra-mural
football. Gray and the Bauer brothers
are members of Alpha Tau Omega.
Hague, although an undergraduate
at Hopkins, has graduated from
Washington college in chemistry.
Each year Tau Beta Pi chooses
six upper classmen. In this year's
crop of initiates, representation was
divided equally between the electrical,
mechanical, and civil engineering
schools. No chemical engineers are
at present members of the fraternity.
The formal initiation took place
last Saturday night at a banquet at
the Hotel Stafford. About 95 members
and alumni attended, including Professor Truman Thompson, head of the
Civil Engineering department.
Speaking after the banquet, Major
Whitman, head of the State Roads
commission, outlined the Commission's program and activities. He admonished his audience to develop interests broader than their jobs after
graduation. An engineer should be
concerned with the community as a
whole, he declared.

Interfraternityboardextended
The Interfraternity board of the Johns Hopkins University voted
unanimously yesterday to extend an invitation to membership to the
following fratel:nities: Alpha Epsilon Pi, Epsilon Tau Alpha, Pi
Lambda Phi, Phi Epsilon Pi, and Phi Sigma Delta.
Jeff Hamilton Board president stated:
"I believe that this action constitutes a very satisfactory settle
ment to a question which has long remained unsolved."
The Interfraternity board, a regulatory body controlling rushing
agreements and other fraternity compacts, will include evey faternity
on the campus, if all invitations are accepted.
The Board's step has been under consideration for several years,
but in the past action has been blocked. The Student council expressed earlier in the year its approval of such a change.

Robert Crosby will head
Junior Prom committee
After serious consideration by the
officers of the Junior class, a committee has been chosen to deal with the
problem of the annual Junior Prom.
chairman,
Robert Crosby was
and his associates will be Thomas
Nicholson, Edward Rubin, Bates
Gray, and Harry Dallas. The boys
are already hard at work picking the
big name band who will be featured,
and Crosby has promised that this
affair will exceed even that of last
year, when Glen Miller "sent" those
present. The date, although not yet
definite, will probably be March 16,
which is one week before Spring vacation.

Al Agrin
corted by Al Agrin, student director.
The Sponsor, as announced last week,
will be Jeanne Callahan; her escort
will be Tom Powers, president of the
club.
Half a dozen old-timers take their
places in the cast, but the majority
of the roles are filled by newcomers
who hope to prove their acting ability
to the campus. A fantastic melange of
characters will bring together figures
of all ages and in all states of mental
unbalance.
It all starts in Olympus, where
Napoleon and St Francis are having
a bit of a quarrel. Two newcomers
have been cast in these roles, Douglas
Goldsmith

taking

Corporal",

and

off
Joseph

the

Shanaphy

playing a calm, eloquent Saint. An
appealing angel is Doris Railing, already well known to Baltimore
theatre-goers.
We then look in on Dunkelstein,
where an enterprising capitalist,
Laban, has full sway, but circumstances cause him to appoint Barber
Cain as the dictator. The part of
money-loving, shallow-minded Laban
is filled by George Newton, while Bill
Locklin assumes the role of the curt,
commanding, Cain, he's in love, too.
Both of the boys have had experience in these types of characters
and are already known on the campus
from previous Barnstormer and Playshop shows.
The love interest is between Laban's daughter, Rachel, and Jacob,
an emmisary from Brazil. Jane
Schaeffner, another experienced thespian, is the daughter who has
troubles with her father, her lover,
and the dictator. Eli Birer, a freshman, is playing the juvenile lead.
Back to heaven again to meet a
hot and sweaty Socrates, played by
another frosh, Walter Traugott. It
seems he is bothered by the "gifts",
but consents to visit earth on a mission of reason, where he is promptly
jailed. Also wandering around heaven
and earth is messenger boy Gabriel,
In reality freshman Billy Himberg.
On earth the chief wandering is
done by Lot, who is addicted to talking to himself, and by Noah, who
hates war but loves his free beer.
The former role is taken by Heibert
Danzer, and the latter by Stan Beal,
who had experience in a comedy role
last year. The bewildered but yet efficient secretary to both Cain and
Laban is Samuel, played by Zoel
Radner, former stage manager for
'Stormer productions.
The play introduces a novel character in the form of a cavorting,
mimicking imp of war. His identity?
It's a mystery!

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1939

Proving
Ground

There's to be more at the
Auditorium tomorrow night
than just an exposition on
relative quantities of peace.
The reception of the 'Stormers' endeavors will decide an
important issue for the

dramatic group.
For many years now the Club has felt cramped
and restricted in its selection of vehicles through an
impression that the campus looked to them purely for
comedy and farce. Many factors contributed to the
feeling. The Club was in a rut as far as variety went,
having produced farces exclusively for some years past.
Many were skeptical of the dramatic ability of the
Club members—doubtful that they could successfully
undertake and complete a real attempt at legitimate
drama. Finally, the choice of an appropriate serious
enterprise, coupled with the aforementioned problems,
always led into such perplexing channels that leading
thespian lights turned from the attempt to the aspirin
bottle and the belly-laughs.
"No More Peace", while not exactly Shakespearean
in its demands, still depends more on pure acting than
many of the previous attempts. The 'Stormers will
be able to get away with a lot, if we understand correctly, under the protection of stage and sound effects,
but acting will play a sufficiently important role so
that if it is under par, the whole play will follow suit.
It will serve to demonstrate something else as well.
"No More Peace" is not original, but it has been
sufficiently student-rewritten, so that if it is successful
we may look to campus talent in the future. Supposedly we're an intellectual and talented student body.
In part, tomorrow night will serve to prove or disprove this supposition.
The whole question is merely part of a much
larger issue which we've mentioned before in these
columns. How much does an activity belong to the
student body, and how much to its constituents? Is
the primary obligation of an activity to the University, that is, to the campus, or is it to concern itself
primarily with the limited desires and fancies of the
men directly participating?
Well, as we see the problem, it resolves itself thus.
Each group should be able to realize what is expected of it by the student body. We feel that its
primary concern must be catering to this demand. Excursions for the sake of experimentation (as in the
present case with the Barnstormers) may be indulged,
but they must not be carried to an extreme, lest activity and campus both suffer. Should such excursions
be well received, they may be incorporated as part of
the policy of that group. But when they are displeasing to the campus, they should be dropped, despite what the activity's membership may think of
them. Unless this is done, all parties concerned will
ultimately suffer. But when such a procedure is followed, each activity will build for itself a tradition of
good-will, yet avoid stagnating in repetition. Several
campus groups might well heed this note.
Tomorrow night then in addition to the usual brilliance, and the 'Stormers coming out party, will incorporate a new significance, and may well determine
what we may expect from our actors in the future.
It will be an interesting demonstration—one which
we wouldn't miss.
The Honor system works
better at the Hopkins than
any proctor system short
of actual policing ever
could. It is a blessing to
instructors, and a tribute to
the regard in which the student body is held by itself and by the faculty. It is
supposedly a tradition; one of which freshmen are
made aware, and of which upper classmen speak to

Return
to
Honor

outsiders with pride. It is less highly touted, but
supposedly autonomic than many similar systems of
other institutions which are more highly publicized.
In short, it's a swell system, but is it an honor system?
What's happened to the Honor system . . . when,
after bandying various regulatory rules for years the
Student council finally says: "We know that, albeit
falsely, reporting a man is considered squealing.
We'll protect you behind the anonimity of the 'slip
system'." Then the Honor commission finds that since
the beginning of the year not one slip has been authentically submitted.
What's happened to the Honor system? . . . when
rumors fly wild on the campus: The business school
is a hot-bed of non-observance; The teacher's college
has never even gotten the system installed on a firm
footing; Such a class and such a class is laughing at
the system. Mention is made of wholesale violations,
yet no one reports specific violations to any extent.
What's happened to the Honor system? . . . when,
even such of us who fought for the system's original
installation (and there are such among the faculty),
and fought for its preservation through the inauguration of the Commission, can at best offer the feeble
apology: "Well, it works better than a proctor system
ever could . ..
We place great stock in campus opinion, but taking polls of sentiment toward the system cannot work.
Students who will express themselves freely otherwise, hesitate to indict the system when asked pointblank. The reasons are obvious. This is one instance, at least, where we are tempted to place more
faith in persistent rumor and gossip than in formal
investigations.
We agree with those who argue the advantages of
our system over a proctor system. But we cannot
reconcile this with our conscience. An Honor system
is one conducted according to each man's personal
honor, not a half-baked substitute. This does not
mean that it works perfectly for all men with honor.
But it does mean that it works perfectly for all men
with Honor at the Hopkins today than are wholeheartedly supporting the system.
But the Honor system is not shot! What it needs
is a little new life and a little more respect from the
student body. When this respect is forthcoming,
there will be no further worry—it will work to practical perfection.
Hopkins has a precious heritage with which it is
playing games. Those of us who feel strongly for the
University and its traditions are moved to wrath. The
Honor system was instituted here as an experiment,
after the diligent effort of conscientious students. It
has been maintained and preserved by similar groups
through the years. But now, in the lackadaisical,
devil-may-care attitude which is in so many ways typical of the Hopkins student body, it is endangered.
Something should and must be done immediately for
shame in the face of what has been in the past.

Two interesting things
happened last week. New
York's gangster-chaser,
Thomas Dewey, launched
campaign for presidential
nomination, censuring New
Deal "defeatism", advocating the re-establishment of a system of "free economy",
and calling for the return of the Republican party to
power in 1940. At the same time a Republican
regime was allowing thousands to starve in Ohio because it wanted to economize.
Mr Dewey's words sounded great if you didn't
think about them too much. By a "free economy",
he seemed to mean one which government does not
attempt to regulate. Adam Smith and Richard Cobden were toying with the same ideal while British
capitalists were keeping their factory workers at the
machines for fourteen hours a day.
Similarly, the epithet of "defeatism" was applied to
the New Deal, apparently because it has recognized
that our economy can not go forward without government support and control. Democrats are defeatistic,
in short, because they don't believe in laissez-faire.
That's a new definition of defeatism but if it's true,
we're all for more defeatism. Business largely unregulated, got America into a pretty bad jam in 1929,
and the Democrats went bouyantly to work mitigating
some of the disadvantages of allowing industrialists to
determine wages and prices. Lacking confidence in
business's willingness to provide for millions of men
which it could not afford to employ New Dealers saved
from economic ruin a large section of the American
people.
While Mr Dewey was asking the nation to turn the
clock back to the good old days of Cobden and Smith,
his fellow-travelers in Ohio were trying to do that
very thing. Opposed to supporting those whom machines have displaced, the Republican-dominated state
slashed its relief appropriation to a ridiculously inadequate figure, and now is taking the consequences.
In the cities, particularly Cleveland, Toledo, and Youngstown, hungry people are prowling the streets in search
of refuse. Yet Republican Governor John W Bricker
declines to lift a finger.
Maybe defeatism isn't the answer to America's
troubles but some people—if not Mr Dewey—prefer
it to famine.

For the past several weeks inh as
tensive basketball practice
been held daily. Three teams have
been sharing the floor, namely the
varsity, the junior varsity, and the
freshman teams. The varsity has
been having senior practice because their first game will be played here tonight. It is believed
that the starting lineup will be picked
from the following: Captain Moore,
Tannenbaum, Knitz, Freyer, Hyde,
Bitsack, T Robinson, and Wagner.
It is very doubtful though if Wagner
will be able to play before Christmas
since he is laid up with a case of
tonsilitis.
Thus far, this year's varsity has
appeared to be a superior team, cornpairing it to last year's outfit. With
the added strength of Hyde, the allstate man from Indiana, Coach Mallonee's hopes are fairly high, and he
has plenty of confidence that his boys
will run right through the Gallaudet
college quintet with little difficulty.
Although last year's team went
through the season winning a majority of their games, Coach Mallonee
expects to see this year's five take
even more of their contests.
The team will see action in one
more game before Christmas after
tonight's, when Towson Teachers
college will journey to Homewood to
engage the Jays in what should prove
to be a lively battle.
After Christmas, four more home
games will be played before exams.
These games are: Wilson Teachers
college, Washington college, Western
Maryland college, and Drexel institute. After exams the team will play
three games away, the outstanding
one probably being played at Swarthmore.
The varsity has been practicing
for Gallaudet in every possible way.
Passing, shooting, blocking, etc have
been covered under the watchful eye
of Coach Mallonee.
The freshmen and jayvee schedules
have not been named definitely as
yet, but the respective coaches have
been working hard to whip their boys
into shape.

Coach McNally has had some difficulty in organizing the junior varsity because so many of them have
classes conflicting with practice, that
it is hard to get them all together at
one time. The coach did, however,
name those men from which his starting lineup would be chosen. They are:
Huther, Remsen, Sheer, Lewis, Sternberg, Thaler, Thomas, and Beck. The
first four are almost certain to be
in the starting lineup, but the coach
did not seem too sure. Coach McNally
has been working under a terrific
handicap this year in trying to get
together a good junior varsity squad.
The conflicts between classes and
practice have been instrumental in
giving the coach a great deal of
trouble in organizing the team. Coach
McNally has hopes of getting the
boys organized within the next few
practices so that they will be an
outstanding ball-club.
The freshman team has shown a
great deal of promise in recent practices. They appear to be a pretty
classy team, and after a few faults
are ironed out, they should prove to
be an excellent team.
The freshmen have made unusually good showings against both the
junior varsity and varsity squads in
scrimmages, and if the coach is able
to keep improving their organization,
by the time of their first game there
is no doubt that they will be handling
and shooting the ball with exceptional
smoothness. The starting five will
probably be chosen from: W Robinson, Stern, Greenbaum, Price, Thanhouser, and Kaestner.

This year, as in previous years,
the fraternity all-stars of this campus
were scheduled to meet the Maryland
college fraternity all-stars in a touchfootball game. For some reason or
other, instead of the Md fraternity
stars coming to Homewood, Maryland's Dorm champs showed up. Well,
the game went on as usual.
Last Saturday's game was divided
into 2 twenty-minute halves. In order
to compromise with Md, the first
half of the game was played according to their rules, and the second
half according to ours. Maryland's
rules are those of association:- each
team has four downs in which they
can try to make a touchdown, and
a forward pass can be thrown on
any part of the field. Hopkins' rules,
includes 5 downs, plus the remaining
regular touch football rules.
Hopkins' line up consisted of the
following players: Captain Wall, and
players Smith, Rossett, Breslau, Tolson, Williams, Checkett and Nicholson.
Maryland's team consisted of:
Captain Kuster, and players Schendell, Hopkins, O'Neil, Elgin, Randdy,
Waters and Bachrach.
The first half, twenty action-filled
minutes, saw Hopkins the victor to
the tune of 18 to 6. In the first few
minutes of play, Tolson intercepted
the ball on a •pass from Schendell.
Avoiding Md players, Tolson passed
to Rossett who recovered the ball
after it was almost knocked from his
hands by •a Md player. Rossett ran
through four opposing players without being touched to score Hopkins'
first 6 points.
After 10 minutes, Kuster, on his
own 30 yard line, punted to the Hopkins 25 yard line. After one play
Tolson passed to Williams. Williams,
in a running play, passed to Nance,
who lateraled to Rossett. Rossett ran
for about 10 yards before throwing
the pig-skin to Breslau who ran the
remaining yardage for a touchdown.
The next kick-off was made by
Nicholson to Maryland who brought
the ball to the Hopkins 25 yard line.
On a sleeper play, Kuster passed to
O'Neil for a touchdown. The score
then stood: Hopkins 12; Maryland 6.
The Dorm champ's goal was soon
followed by a Hopkins' touchdown.
Nance, who was injured in an attempt
to snatch a long pass by Nicholson
from the air, was replaced by Smith.
Captain Wall, in the next play, passed to Erskine who lateraled to
Rossett. Rossett completed the play
for a touchdown. The remaining minutes of the first half saw the ball seesaw up and down the field, with no
more scoring by either team.

THE NEWS -LETTER

First debate
to go on radio
That a national radio hookup will
carry the Debating council's first
engagement of the season, next February 3, was revealed by council
spokesmen late yesterday afternoon.
The encounter, which is to take place
at the University of Pennsylvania,
will be an invitation affair and one of
the first of a limited series arranged
by the Philadelphia school.
Although a complete schedule has
not been prepared as yet, it will be
forthcoming on or about January 15.
The radio broadcast will be the
first thing of its kind in the annals
of the Hopkins. "The recent increase
of general interest among the administration and student body leads
us to expect a more than successful
season," stated Carrington Williams,
president of the council.
When questioned on the aspects of
the extended program, Nat Miller,
council manager, remarked, "Because
of the improvement in the organization and the methods of the Debating
council within the last two years,
opportunities for the success of capable aspirants have been greatly enhanced."
Contrary to former policy, the debators will argue three topics this
year. The main selection, choice of
the National Debating Council, is
Resolved, That •the United States
should follow a policy of strict economic and military isolation outside
the Western Hemisphere towards all
nations engaged in armed international or civil conflict.
The selection of the two auxiliary
topics will depend on the tabulation
of intercollegiate correspondence on
popular topics soon after the holidays.

Chains to Lose
By Ed Oppenheimer

The Turncoats of Saville Row
Mr H N Brailsford, the London
correspondent of the New Republic,
sounds off this week, with a touching faith in British ideals that I, perhaps too skeptically, refuse to share.
He begins by saying: "Today, however, the Labor Party is incomparably stronger that it was then, (referring to the Versailles treaty), and
as yet there is among British Tories
no trace of the grasping and vindictive spirit that wrecked the peace of
1918 . . . English thinking is busied
today with ideas more constructive
than the drawing of maps, and this
time not a solitary voice calls for
indemnities. It is the frontiers of
freedom that Englishmen wish to extend. This for them is a war to end
the Fascist Secession that shattered
the unity of Western civilization."
To many, the British cause appears
clad in the garments of righteousness
because it is fighting an ugly and
horrible monstrosity among human
institutions—the Nazi dictatorship.
But I don't see any such shining
knight in the role of the British. The
picture of Frankenstein's creator
wrestling with his monster who has
gotten too strong for him, and trying
to beat the monster down again, so
he will be more serviceable, is I think,
an apter analogy.
For one thing, the Hitler group
could never have reached the degree
of power that it has now without
the tacit consent of certain dominant
groups within England. The proBritish group of German industrialists headed by Thyssen, who has recently been forced out, was strongly

aided by the Rothermere-Beaverbrook interests and the politicians
who represented them, in their attempt to install a dictator who would
check the Soviet threat to British
domination of the European economy.
Secondly, the Labor Party among
other groups was responsible for
sabotaging any British participation
in collective-security policy against
Fascist aggressors in the past five
years. They failed to make a working coalition against Chamberlain
with the Liberals, letting his earlier
pro-Nazi overtures go unchecked.
Since the last war, all British policy

Singewald speaks on war minerals
at Tau Beta Pi semi-annual tap
Geologist says Germany
lacks mineral power
Speaking as the second lecturer in
a series of non-compulsory assemblies sponsored by the NEWS-LETTER
and the Assembly committee, Dr J
T Singewald discussed yesterday the
Importance of mineral resources in
the current war. As an illustration of
the great role these resources play in
determining the political structure
of a nation, Dr Singewald stated
that it was largely through their
absence that totalitarian governments
come into being.
"Countries are divided into the
have got and the haven't got", the
lecturer stated, "and on this crux
hangs their foreign policies." The
current alignment of nations seems
to bear out this fact, as Germany
may have to depend largely on the resources of Russia, while the British
empire is in position to supply the
Allies. However, these lines of supply
are in turn dependent on the control
of transportation and commerce, and
that control is easily variable.
Dr Singewald divided the pertinent
resources into three groups; the nonmetals, the metals, and fuel. Both
sides in the conflict are adequately
supplied with the non-metals, composed mainly of fertilizers; both also
have plenty of coal and either petroleum or a synthetic substitute. In regard to metals, however, a different
picture is presented. Germany has
neither gold nor silver, and must depend on exports for cerdit—and these
exports will be seriously diminished
by the war. Germany also is in a
critical situation in regard to many
metals of war, and is notably short
of mercury, the source of fulminate.
Dr Singewald stated that in respect
to this and antimony, the question
has been raised as to whether Germany has been able to stock up a
supply; she probably has not, due to
the stringent circumstances of the
last few years.
As an illustration of the importance of colonies, Dr Singewald showed the relatively poor status of England alone and the great resources
at her command with the addition
of her colonies. Now there are only
two metals at all strategic for the
Allies, and they may be had from
neutral nations. Germany, on the
other hand, has twelve critical necessities, all of which may be had except two, assuming the support of
Russia.
The next and last lecture in the
series on the international scene will
be presented January 11 by Dr Kent
Roberts Greenfield, who will discuss
the Mediterranean region and its
significance in the war.

Council approves
Honor appointees
The six new appointees to the
Honor commission were unanimously
approved at a meeting of the Student council on Friday, December 8.
The Freshman representatives are
Bob Burr, Robert Cross, Peter Stern
and Morty Hack, John McGee and
Wray Hoffman are the two upper
classmen just elected to the commission.
The Louisiana State university has
recently written to the commission
about the honor system. Stating the
fact that L S U would like to institute a similar system, the letter
asked about the workings of the plan
here at the Hopkins and about the
rules governing its application.
Some members of the Commission
believe that the freshman class does
not understand the full import of
the honor system. If necessary, the
Honor commission plans a further
period of education similar to the
one the new students had at the beginning of the academic year.

Hague, Depkin, Gosnell,
Gray, Bauer boys tapped
Tau Beta Pi, honorary engineering
men at a

fraternity, inducted six

public tap preceding Dr Singewald'P
address at the assembly yesterday.
Four seniors—Charles Hague, Charles
Depkin, John Gray, and Don Bauer,
and two juniors—William Gosnell
and Jack Bauer, were admitted.
After a short explanation of the
requirements and purpose of the fraternity, Charles Rothauge, chapter
president, brought the six men up to
the stage and awarded each his bent.
Although the primary requisite for
membership is scholarship, most of
the entrants have engaged in extracurricular activities. Gosnell, a football player for the past two years, is
also president of his class. Hague and
Depkin are active in intra-mural
football. Gray and the Bauer brothers
are members of Alpha Tau Omega.
Hague, although an undergraduate
at Hopkins, has graduated from
Washington college in chemistry.
Each year Tau Beta Pi chooses
six upper classmen. In this year's
crop of initiates, representation was
divided equally between the electrical,
mechanical, and civil engineering
schools. No chemical engineers are
at present members of the fraternity.
The formal initiation took place
last Saturday night at a banquet at
the Hotel Stafford. About 95 members
and alumni attended, including Professor Truman Thompson, head of the
Civil Engineering department.
Speaking after the banquet, Major
Whitman, head of the State Roads
commission, outlined the Commission's program and activities. He admonished his audience to develop interests broader than their jobs after
graduation. An engineer should be
concerned with the community as a
whole, he declared.

Interfraternityboardextended
The Interfraternity board of the Johns Hopkins University voted
unanimously yesterday to extend an invitation to membership to the
following fratel:nities: Alpha Epsilon Pi, Epsilon Tau Alpha, Pi
Lambda Phi, Phi Epsilon Pi, and Phi Sigma Delta.
Jeff Hamilton Board president stated:
"I believe that this action constitutes a very satisfactory settle
ment to a question which has long remained unsolved."
The Interfraternity board, a regulatory body controlling rushing
agreements and other fraternity compacts, will include evey faternity
on the campus, if all invitations are accepted.
The Board's step has been under consideration for several years,
but in the past action has been blocked. The Student council expressed earlier in the year its approval of such a change.

FRIDAY, DECEMBER 15, 1939

Proving
Ground

There's to be more at the
Auditorium tomorrow night
than just an exposition on
relative quantities of peace.
The reception of the 'Stormers' endeavors will decide an
important issue for the

dramatic group.
For many years now the Club has felt cramped
and restricted in its selection of vehicles through an
impression that the campus looked to them purely for
comedy and farce. Many factors contributed to the
feeling. The Club was in a rut as far as variety went,
having produced farces exclusively for some years past.
Many were skeptical of the dramatic ability of the
Club members—doubtful that they could successfully
undertake and complete a real attempt at legitimate
drama. Finally, the choice of an appropriate serious
enterprise, coupled with the aforementioned problems,
always led into such perplexing channels that leading
thespian lights turned from the attempt to the aspirin
bottle and the belly-laughs.
"No More Peace", while not exactly Shakespearean
in its demands, still depends more on pure acting than
many of the previous attempts. The 'Stormers will
be able to get away with a lot, if we understand correctly, under the protection of stage and sound effects,
but acting will play a sufficiently important role so
that if it is under par, the whole play will follow suit.
It will serve to demonstrate something else as well.
"No More Peace" is not original, but it has been
sufficiently student-rewritten, so that if it is successful
we may look to campus talent in the future. Supposedly we're an intellectual and talented student body.
In part, tomorrow night will serve to prove or disprove this supposition.
The whole question is merely part of a much
larger issue which we've mentioned before in these
columns. How much does an activity belong to the
student body, and how much to its constituents? Is
the primary obligation of an activity to the University, that is, to the campus, or is it to concern itself
primarily with the limited desires and fancies of the
men directly participating?
Well, as we see the problem, it resolves itself thus.
Each group should be able to realize what is expected of it by the student body. We feel that its
primary concern must be catering to this demand. Excursions for the sake of experimentation (as in the
present case with the Barnstormers) may be indulged,
but they must not be carried to an extreme, lest activity and campus both suffer. Should such excursions
be well received, they may be incorporated as part of
the policy of that group. But when they are displeasing to the campus, they should be dropped, despite what the activity's membership may think of
them. Unless this is done, all parties concerned will
ultimately suffer. But when such a procedure is followed, each activity will build for itself a tradition of
good-will, yet avoid stagnating in repetition. Several
campus groups might well heed this note.
Tomorrow night then in addition to the usual brilliance, and the 'Stormers coming out party, will incorporate a new significance, and may well determine
what we may expect from our actors in the future.
It will be an interesting demonstration—one which
we wouldn't miss.
The Honor system works
better at the Hopkins than
any proctor system short
of actual policing ever
could. It is a blessing to
instructors, and a tribute to
the regard in which the student body is held by itself and by the faculty. It is
supposedly a tradition; one of which freshmen are
made aware, and of which upper classmen speak to

Return
to
Honor

outsiders with pride. It is less highly touted, but
supposedly autonomic than many similar systems of
other institutions which are more highly publicized.
In short, it's a swell system, but is it an honor system?
What's happened to the Honor system . . . when,
after bandying various regulatory rules for years the
Student council finally says: "We know that, albeit
falsely, reporting a man is considered squealing.
We'll protect you behind the anonimity of the 'slip
system'." Then the Honor commission finds that since
the beginning of the year not one slip has been authentically submitted.
What's happened to the Honor system? . . . when
rumors fly wild on the campus: The business school
is a hot-bed of non-observance; The teacher's college
has never even gotten the system installed on a firm
footing; Such a class and such a class is laughing at
the system. Mention is made of wholesale violations,
yet no one reports specific violations to any extent.
What's happened to the Honor system? . . . when,
even such of us who fought for the system's original
installation (and there are such among the faculty),
and fought for its preservation through the inauguration of the Commission, can at best offer the feeble
apology: "Well, it works better than a proctor system
ever could . ..
We place great stock in campus opinion, but taking polls of sentiment toward the system cannot work.
Students who will express themselves freely otherwise, hesitate to indict the system when asked pointblank. The reasons are obvious. This is one instance, at least, where we are tempted to place more
faith in persistent rumor and gossip than in formal
investigations.
We agree with those who argue the advantages of
our system over a proctor system. But we cannot
reconcile this with our conscience. An Honor system
is one conducted according to each man's personal
honor, not a half-baked substitute. This does not
mean that it works perfectly for all men with honor.
But it does mean that it works perfectly for all men
with Honor at the Hopkins today than are wholeheartedly supporting the system.
But the Honor system is not shot! What it needs
is a little new life and a little more respect from the
student body. When this respect is forthcoming,
there will be no further worry—it will work to practical perfection.
Hopkins has a precious heritage with which it is
playing games. Those of us who feel strongly for the
University and its traditions are moved to wrath. The
Honor system was instituted here as an experiment,
after the diligent effort of conscientious students. It
has been maintained and preserved by similar groups
through the years. But now, in the lackadaisical,
devil-may-care attitude which is in so many ways typical of the Hopkins student body, it is endangered.
Something should and must be done immediately for
shame in the face of what has been in the past.

had told us last week that we had

Two interesting things
happened last week. New
York's gangster-chaser,
Thomas Dewey, launched
campaign for presidential
nomination, censuring New
Deal "defeatism", advocating the re-establishment of a system of "free economy",
and calling for the return of the Republican party to
power in 1940. At the same time a Republican
regime was allowing thousands to starve in Ohio because it wanted to economize.
Mr Dewey's words sounded great if you didn't
think about them too much. By a "free economy",
he seemed to mean one which government does not
attempt to regulate. Adam Smith and Richard Cobden were toying with the same ideal while British
capitalists were keeping their factory workers at the
machines for fourteen hours a day.
Similarly, the epithet of "defeatism" was applied to
the New Deal, apparently because it has recognized
that our economy can not go forward without government support and control. Democrats are defeatistic,
in short, because they don't believe in laissez-faire.
That's a new definition of defeatism but if it's true,
we're all for more defeatism. Business largely unregulated, got America into a pretty bad jam in 1929,
and the Democrats went bouyantly to work mitigating
some of the disadvantages of allowing industrialists to
determine wages and prices. Lacking confidence in
business's willingness to provide for millions of men
which it could not afford to employ New Dealers saved
from economic ruin a large section of the American
people.
While Mr Dewey was asking the nation to turn the
clock back to the good old days of Cobden and Smith,
his fellow-travelers in Ohio were trying to do that
very thing. Opposed to supporting those whom machines have displaced, the Republican-dominated state
slashed its relief appropriation to a ridiculously inadequate figure, and now is taking the consequences.
In the cities, particularly Cleveland, Toledo, and Youngstown, hungry people are prowling the streets in search
of refuse. Yet Republican Governor John W Bricker
declines to lift a finger.
Maybe defeatism isn't the answer to America's
troubles but some people—if not Mr Dewey—prefer
it to famine.

For the past several weeks inh as
tensive basketball practice
been held daily. Three teams have
been sharing the floor, namely the
varsity, the junior varsity, and the
freshman teams. The varsity has
been having senior practice because their first game will be played here tonight. It is believed
that the starting lineup will be picked
from the following: Captain Moore,
Tannenbaum, Knitz, Freyer, Hyde,
Bitsack, T Robinson, and Wagner.
It is very doubtful though if Wagner
will be able to play before Christmas
since he is laid up with a case of
tonsilitis.
Thus far, this year's varsity has
appeared to be a superior team, cornpairing it to last year's outfit. With
the added strength of Hyde, the allstate man from Indiana, Coach Mallonee's hopes are fairly high, and he
has plenty of confidence that his boys
will run right through the Gallaudet
college quintet with little difficulty.
Although last year's team went
through the season winning a majority of their games, Coach Mallonee
expects to see this year's five take
even more of their contests.
The team will see action in one
more game before Christmas after
tonight's, when Towson Teachers
college will journey to Homewood to
engage the Jays in what should prove
to be a lively battle.
After Christmas, four more home
games will be played before exams.
These games are: Wilson Teachers
college, Washington college, Western
Maryland college, and Drexel institute. After exams the team will play
three games away, the outstanding
one probably being played at Swarthmore.
The varsity has been practicing
for Gallaudet in every possible way.
Passing, shooting, blocking, etc have
been covered under the watchful eye
of Coach Mallonee.
The freshmen and jayvee schedules
have not been named definitely as
yet, but the respective coaches have
been working hard to whip their boys
into shape.

Coach McNally has had some difficulty in organizing the junior varsity because so many of them have
classes conflicting with practice, that
it is hard to get them all together at
one time. The coach did, however,
name those men from which his starting lineup would be chosen. They are:
Huther, Remsen, Sheer, Lewis, Sternberg, Thaler, Thomas, and Beck. The
first four are almost certain to be
in the starting lineup, but the coach
did not seem too sure. Coach McNally
has been working under a terrific
handicap this year in trying to get
together a good junior varsity squad.
The conflicts between classes and
practice have been instrumental in
giving the coach a great deal of
trouble in organizing the team. Coach
McNally has hopes of getting the
boys organized within the next few
practices so that they will be an
outstanding ball-club.
The freshman team has shown a
great deal of promise in recent practices. They appear to be a pretty
classy team, and after a few faults
are ironed out, they should prove to
be an excellent team.
The freshmen have made unusually good showings against both the
junior varsity and varsity squads in
scrimmages, and if the coach is able
to keep improving their organization,
by the time of their first game there
is no doubt that they will be handling
and shooting the ball with exceptional
smoothness. The starting five will
probably be chosen from: W Robinson, Stern, Greenbaum, Price, Thanhouser, and Kaestner.

Md champs

This year, as in previous years,
the fraternity all-stars of this campus
were scheduled to meet the Maryland
college fraternity all-stars in a touchfootball game. For some reason or
other, instead of the Md fraternity
stars coming to Homewood, Maryland's Dorm champs showed up. Well,
the game went on as usual.
Last Saturday's game was divided
into 2 twenty-minute halves. In order
to compromise with Md, the first
half of the game was played according to their rules, and the second
half according to ours. Maryland's
rules are those of association:- each
team has four downs in which they
can try to make a touchdown, and
a forward pass can be thrown on
any part of the field. Hopkins' rules,
includes 5 downs, plus the remaining
regular touch football rules.
Hopkins' line up consisted of the
following players: Captain Wall, and
players Smith, Rossett, Breslau, Tolson, Williams, Checkett and Nicholson.
Maryland's team consisted of:
Captain Kuster, and players Schendell, Hopkins, O'Neil, Elgin, Randdy,
Waters and Bachrach.
The first half, twenty action-filled
minutes, saw Hopkins the victor to
the tune of 18 to 6. In the first few
minutes of play, Tolson intercepted
the ball on a •pass from Schendell.
Avoiding Md players, Tolson passed
to Rossett who recovered the ball
after it was almost knocked from his
hands by •a Md player. Rossett ran
through four opposing players without being touched to score Hopkins'
first 6 points.
After 10 minutes, Kuster, on his
own 30 yard line, punted to the Hopkins 25 yard line. After one play
Tolson passed to Williams. Williams,
in a running play, passed to Nance,
who lateraled to Rossett. Rossett ran
for about 10 yards before throwing
the pig-skin to Breslau who ran the
remaining yardage for a touchdown.
The next kick-off was made by
Nicholson to Maryland who brought
the ball to the Hopkins 25 yard line.
On a sleeper play, Kuster passed to
O'Neil for a touchdown. The score
then stood: Hopkins 12; Maryland 6.
The Dorm champ's goal was soon
followed by a Hopkins' touchdown.
Nance, who was injured in an attempt
to snatch a long pass by Nicholson
from the air, was replaced by Smith.
Captain Wall, in the next play, passed to Erskine who lateraled to
Rossett. Rossett completed the play
for a touchdown. The remaining minutes of the first half saw the ball seesaw up and down the field, with no
more scoring by either team.

THE NEWS -LETTER

First debate
to go on radio
That a national radio hookup will
carry the Debating council's first
engagement of the season, next February 3, was revealed by council
spokesmen late yesterday afternoon.
The encounter, which is to take place
at the University of Pennsylvania,
will be an invitation affair and one of
the first of a limited series arranged
by the Philadelphia school.
Although a complete schedule has
not been prepared as yet, it will be
forthcoming on or about January 15.
The radio broadcast will be the
first thing of its kind in the annals
of the Hopkins. "The recent increase
of general interest among the administration and student body leads
us to expect a more than successful
season," stated Carrington Williams,
president of the council.
When questioned on the aspects of
the extended program, Nat Miller,
council manager, remarked, "Because
of the improvement in the organization and the methods of the Debating
council within the last two years,
opportunities for the success of capable aspirants have been greatly enhanced."
Contrary to former policy, the debators will argue three topics this
year. The main selection, choice of
the National Debating Council, is
Resolved, That •the United States
should follow a policy of strict economic and military isolation outside
the Western Hemisphere towards all
nations engaged in armed international or civil conflict.
The selection of the two auxiliary
topics will depend on the tabulation
of intercollegiate correspondence on
popular topics soon after the holidays.

Chains to Lose
By Ed Oppenheimer

The Turncoats of Saville Row
Mr H N Brailsford, the London
correspondent of the New Republic,
sounds off this week, with a touching faith in British ideals that I, perhaps too skeptically, refuse to share.
He begins by saying: "Today, however, the Labor Party is incomparably stronger that it was then, (referring to the Versailles treaty), and
as yet there is among British Tories
no trace of the grasping and vindictive spirit that wrecked the peace of
1918 . . . English thinking is busied
today with ideas more constructive
than the drawing of maps, and this
time not a solitary voice calls for
indemnities. It is the frontiers of
freedom that Englishmen wish to extend. This for them is a war to end
the Fascist Secession that shattered
the unity of Western civilization."
To many, the British cause appears
clad in the garments of righteousness
because it is fighting an ugly and
horrible monstrosity among human
institutions—the Nazi dictatorship.
But I don't see any such shining
knight in the role of the British. The
picture of Frankenstein's creator
wrestling with his monster who has
gotten too strong for him, and trying
to beat the monster down again, so
he will be more serviceable, is I think,
an apter analogy.
For one thing, the Hitler group
could never have reached the degree
of power that it has now without
the tacit consent of certain dominant
groups within England. The proBritish group of German industrialists headed by Thyssen, who has recently been forced out, was strongly

aided by the Rothermere-Beaverbrook interests and the politicians
who represented them, in their attempt to install a dictator who would
check the Soviet threat to British
domination of the European economy.
Secondly, the Labor Party among
other groups was responsible for
sabotaging any British participation
in collective-security policy against
Fascist aggressors in the past five
years. They failed to make a working coalition against Chamberlain
with the Liberals, letting his earlier
pro-Nazi overtures go unchecked.
Since the last war, all British policy

for peace was sounded.
